title: Hello World
description:
In this tutorial, you will create a hello world service to have a quick feeling
on how Gazel works.

children.value:
In this tutorial, you will create a hello world service to have a quick feeling
on how Gazel works.
To create a new business service, create a class named

│       └── TodoManager.cs
└── test
    └── Inventiv.Sample.Test.Todo

That's it. Now you can run this test to see if it succeeds.
Gazel uses NUnit for unit testing. For more information about NUnit see:

As you can see no configuration is needed to create a new service. Once you've
created your solution and projects, every public class in

projects
becomes a service package and every public method becomes a service by
convention.
Now try to add new methods or add parameters, re-run and see the results.

Once you are ready, you can proceed to create your first database operation
using Gazel.

title: Persistent Classes
description:
In this tutorial, you will create a persistent class and make your first
database operation using Gazel.

database operation using Gazel.

First property is mandatory for all persistent classes. Gazel requires an
integer Id column for every table.

These properties are automatically mapped to columns of

Note that you don't have to create tables and columns in your SQLite
database.  When in local development mode, Gazel configures NHibernate's
SQLite connection to automatically create database schema.

For persistent classes construction is in two steps. First step is the actual

"Write Tests"

class. It basically helps you to check

When testing, Gazel configures a fake service application in which there is a
database connection to an in-memory SQLite database. For every test case, it
begins a transaction and rollbacks after execution.

Like manager classes, persistent classes also follow conventions. In this
tutorial you've created a table and a create service using no configuration.
Now try to add new properties to

class or add new persistent
classes, re-run and see the results.

Once you are ready, you can proceed to learn how to update a record in
database.

title: Database Transactions
description:
In this tutorial, you will create an update service and learn about how Gazel
manages database transactions.

children.value:
In this tutorial, you will create an update service and learn about how Gazel
manages database transactions.

Now that you've created task cards, it's time to complete them. To do this add
following method to your
And that's it. You've created a

There is no need to create a database transaction, before every service call
Gazel automatically opens a database connection and begins a transaction.

Notice that you don't have to call an update method in repository. Gazel
configures NHibernate in auto update mode. This means it makes a dirty check
upon commit and update rows when there is a change.
again. Now you will see a

service
package and under this package there is

service. Since this service
requires a row in database,
Go and create a task card using
When you press call button you will see following screen;
You may remember that we used

access modifier on property setters
as shown below;

setters ensure that data of a persistent object
can only be updated within its own class. Gazel is designed to welcome business
services on persistent classes.

setters, that is fine too. But this would make it
possible to update a property value from outside. This is because we use auto
update feature of NHibernate.

Always remember that persistent objects in Gazel are not simle DTOs. They are
context aware domain objects that manages a row in a database.
Let's move on to testing. Now add following test to your

object and create a task card named "Write
Tests"
: Assert that task card is completed

. This is
because for this test case creating a task card is a part of the

In this tutorial you've learned how to write a simple update service to a
method. Now try to add new properties and methods to your persistent classes,
re-run and see the results.
Once you are ready, you can proceed to learn how to write query services.

title: Query Classes
description:
In this tutorial, you will create a query service and learn about query service
conventions.

children.value:
In this tutorial, you will create a query service and learn about query service
conventions.

Now you will create a query service to see all completed task cards. Add below
code to

base class, and it simply accepts a
lambda expression with one parameter of type

Like every public method, this query method is also exposed as a business
service. Build and run
to see your completed task cards.

When a query method returns a list of objects, the convention is to name it
as

When a query method takes only one parameter, method name contains
parameter name as a suffix.
So by these conventions we named this query as
Now add following test case to your

shortcut to access query classes.
Unlike

projects as
well, so that you don't have to inject query classes.

Query classes help you to organize your query methods for the same persistent
class into one place, so that you can create reusable query methods.

Now try to create other query methods that accepts more than one parameter,
re-run and see the results.

Once you are ready, you can proceed to learn how to create service packages and
expose your business services publicly.

title: Rest API
description:
In this tutorial, you will create a Rest API and learn about configuration and
api packaging.

children.value:
In this tutorial, you will create a Rest API and learn about configuration and
api packaging.

Until now you've created business services for internal use. By internal we
mean that they are supposed to be consumed by your applications only. You can
always publish your business services directly to outside but this would be
hard for you to maintain and refactor your business code. For this reason, you
will create an api package out of your business services.

First we will define which services to expose. To do this, create a folder
named

and under this folder create an interface
named

props.code:
Inventiv.Sample
├── src
│   ├── Inventiv.Sample.App.Rest
│   ├── Inventiv.Sample.App.Service
│   └── Inventiv.Sample.Module.Todo
│       ├── Service
│       │   └── ITaskCardService.cs
│       ├── TodoManager.cs
│       └── TaskCard.cs
└── test
    └── Inventiv.Sample.Test.Todo

children.value:

├── src
│   ├── Inventiv.Sample.App.Rest

│   └── Inventiv.Sample.Module.Todo
│       ├── Service
│       │   └── ITaskCardService.cs
│       ├── TodoManager.cs
│       └── TaskCard.cs
└── test
    └── Inventiv.Sample.Test.Todo
and it will contain the methods of
class that you want to share with the outside world.

You will see your first endpoint in Swagger UI;

Try your endpoint by making an HTTP request to this URL, and make sure you use
an id value from your test database in place of

Resource name is in plural because you named your web service package after a
persistent class,
There are 3 new interfaces in your service definition;

Implement your new interfaces as shown below;
Notice that we make use of

to map
interface methods to class methods. This is required for methods of service
interfaces where return type in service interface is different than the
return type in implementing class. e.g.
And finally add new interfaces to your api package;
You now have 4 endpoints to test;
Go ahead and test your endpoints!

In this section you've learned how to create a Rest API out of your business
services.
Now try to create new persistent objects to enhance your to-do application.
You can move to next section to download a complete to-do application.

title: Sample Application
description:
This tutorial is only a small portion of how you can build a backend solution,
but there is much more to learn about Gazel.

children.value:
This tutorial is only a small portion of how you can build a backend solution,
but there is much more to learn about Gazel.
Here you can download a complete

with all endpoints and
functionality. Examine it to have a better feeling of how you can build a
similar solution.

You can continue to read this documentation to have a deeper understanding of
how Gazel works.

to see all conventions Gazel
exposes.

to learn about the underlying
architectural design.

to learn what options you have and how
to change the way Gazel behaves.
